en_first_half: A little smoke couldn’t be noticed now, so we would take some fish off of the lines and cook up a hot breakfast. And afterwards we would watch the lonesomeness of the river, and kind of lazy along, and by-and-by lazy off to sleep. Wake up by-and-by, and look to see what done it, and maybe see a steamboat coughing along up-stream, so far off towards the other side you couldn’t tell nothing about her only whether she was a stern-wheel or side-wheel; then for about an hour there wouldn’t be nothing to hear nor nothing to see—just solid lonesomeness. Next you’d see a raft sliding by, away off yonder, and maybe a galoot on it chopping, because they’re most always doing it on a raft; you’d see the axe
en_second_half: flash and come down—you don’t hear nothing; you see that axe go up again, and by the time it’s above the man’s head then you hear the k’chunk!—it had took all that time to come over the water. So we would put in the day, lazying around, listening to the stillness. Once there was a thick fog, and the rafts and things that went by was beating tin pans so the steamboats wouldn’t run over them. A scow or a raft went by so close we could hear them talking and cussing and laughing—heard them plain; but we couldn’t see no sign of them; it made you feel crawly; it was like spirits carrying on that way in the air. Jim said he believed it was spirits; but I says:
en_results_raw: strike the log and come out again and go on and stop to rest, and the result was that by the time it was clipped the raft was a hundred yards by and a half mile further down. Then we would drop below to one of the islands to have dinner. Jim liked to cook. He said it was about the only thing his pap left him. So Jim got out some corn-dodgers and buttermilk, and pork and cabbage and greens—there ain't nothing better, and the cabbage and greens was considerable more than half-raw. We got that from our small garden which was on the Kentucky side, eight mile below this island. We had to be mighty quiet laying it in, and when we got done we had to take the canoe clear around the upper head of the island, nearly a mile, to get to the raft again, so the folks on the steamboats wouldn't see us. We laid there all day, and watched the rafts and steamboats, and talked about our journey. Sometimes we would pull up to a willow and hide and then some steamboat would come tearing along, that thought she was a-whaling. We would watch her come plowing along under a good head of steam, and see the men run to bank her and we would hear them whooping and yelling. Then she would go tearing by so close we could hear the rush of the water. Then the men would go to pushing her off with a pole, and then we would hear her diminishing whoops, and finally after a long time her lights burning at the stern. Then we would see her steam die out a long ways down the river, and so she would go on her journey's way to Orleans. We had to lay snug and keep mighty quiet when they come along, or maybe they would hear us and come aboard to give us a rub-a-dub with the boot-jack. Every now and then we would see a small boat moving along close to the shore, and we knew it was somebody hunting for something that was lost overboard. We would pull in close and ask them what they were hunting for. Sometimes it was a hat or a coat or a barrel of flour and sometimes it was a man. Yes, many was the man drifting down the Mississippi on a raft that way, and many a wife has become a widow from that foolishness. We would tell them we hadn't seen nothing and pull on, and they would go on. Sometimes we would see a log or a saw-log raft, and the men would be on it riding their own private raft. We would hail them and they would answer, and we would pull up and they would take us aboard and we would ride with them, and they would show us the sights along the river. They would take us to where the big cypress and tupelo trees grow that spreads out like a roof, so that it is as dark as a house underneath, and the trunks of the trees seven to ten feet through and sixty to eighty feet without a limb. They would show us the oxbow lakes and the cut-offs and the new and old river, and tell us about the time when the river was changed from the old to the new, and how the people at that time was drowned, and we would see the monument that told how it happened, and the names of the people that got drowned. And then we would bid them adieu, and they would get off on a sand-bar, and we would go on down the river. We would have from one to two weeks or a month on the river, according to the stages of the water, and we would take in all these sights, and have the best kind of times, and I ain't going to tell it all yet, because I want to be doing something else just now.
